newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia wheat faces new weather scare - AWB.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia wheat faces new weather scare - AWB.

text.p: Fears of a wet harvest for part of the 1996/97 Australian wheat crop were sparked by nerves but backed by forecasts of more rain on the way, Alex Nichol, communications manager of the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) said.
There had been some damage to the Queensland crop, he said, although the extent of it remained unclear.
"With a big crop out there there is a degree of nervousness amongst growers," he said.
AWB analysts say two weather changes are approaching, with the potential to bring rain, he said.
"Crops are just at the vulnerable stage in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales right now," he said.
Rain was predicted for next week, then further rain five days after that, he said.
It would take some time before the full extent of recent rain damage in southern Queensland was known, he said.
Deliveries which the AWB was receiving at present were still above feed grade, but it was difficult to draw conclusions from that at present, he said.
The Australian harvest commences in central Queensland, the northernmost part of the wheatbelt, in October and peaks in the December-January period further south and west.
Recent rain and the prospect of more rain has exerted downward pressure on Australian wheat futures prices in recent days.
Most forecasts put the 1996/97 crop around 20 million tonnes although some grain trade sources say it could match the 1983/84 record crop of 22 million tonnes.
